For someone beginning the shooting sports, I would recommned a 22LR rifle. A fairly simple one, but expandable. Bolt or semi-auto doesn't matter. It should be able to take a scope in the future. Don't go with the cheapest one you can find, but get a brand name. I wish I could recommend a particular model, but it's been a while since I bought a 22 rifle. I'm mostly a pistol guy. Winchester, Marlin and Remington all have good quality 22s for about $130. A decent scope and you have a lifetime of fun. Pop cans at 100 yards!
 
 Get a cleaning kit and use it.
 
 22s are probably the most fun and cheapest to shoot of all firearms. I have a Ruger 22/45 pistol and have a ball with it all for a couple of bucks in ammo. I can't shoot any other caliber that cheaply, even reloading.

 My personal opinion is it is hard to beat a 12 ga., short-barreled shotgun for overall defense of one's residence. I have a reletivly inexpensive Winchester Defender model 12 ga. pump with a barrel 1/2" longer than legal. The magazine tube extends to the end of the barrel and holds seven 2 3/4" standard shells or six 3" magnums.(8 & 7 respectivly with one in the pipe) I have mounted a small mag-lite flashlight underneath the mag tube for shedding light on anything that might go bump in the night.
 
 I would also agree that a .22 rifle (the Ruger 10-22 being a fine choice) is the best way to get started in shooting if you have no experience. It's best to start with smaller rounds and work your way up. If you shoot enough, the urge for more powerful weapons will come naturally. On the other hand, I've seen inexperienced shooters become completely turned off guns after an afternoon of shooting high-powered rifles, or shotguns when they don't shoulder them properly and wake the next morning in pain, with their arm and shoulder all black and blue.
